application_protocol.name: product_life_cycle_support
application_protocol.title: Product life cycle support
application_protocol.keywords: Application protocol, product life cycle support, configuration management

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol for the representation of product life cycle support (PLCS). It provides a comprehensive capability to describe a set of products needing support and the work required to sustain such products in an operational condition.

AP239 enables the creation and management through time of an Assured set of Product and Support Information (APSI) which can be used to specify and control required support activities throughout a product's life. This information is assumed to be subject to configuration change management, applied to sustain the information needed to support the product, in line with the changing product, over its full life cycle.

Capability is also provided to describe the resources required, provided and used to deliver support, and to record the history of the product usage, state and work done. AP239 also includes modules to support the representation of structured requirements. (CAN WE MAKE SOME ACKNOWLEDGEMENT TO AP233 HERE?
The PLCS vision is shown in Figure 1.
The vision shows how relevant information required for life cycle support can be collected into an integrated form. This life cycle data has two components:

ul.li: the APSI, which defines the product and its support, and is subject to Configuration Change Management;
and Related Information, including feedback on the history of the product, activities and resoucres, which may be superceded, but is not usually subject to Configuration Management.

purpose.p: Relevant applications will enable maintainers and other support staff to query this life cycle data as needed. The response could include instructions tailored to the individual product, location and activities. If required for assurance purposes, AP239 could also hold a copy of the query response. This data could also be used to populate aspects of any feedback report required on completion of an activity. APSI can also be used by work planning applications. This may include generating a list of resources needed at a particular location, for a given period, to support planned activities. Structured information from such a plan could be used to populate transaction messages within an ERP, or similar, system used to operate a supply chain. Information from supply chain transactions could be extracted to update aspects the life cycle data, such as current resource locations.

AP239 was developed to represent the data associated with complex engineering assets, such as aircraft, ships or weapon systems, which may exist either as a product design, or as realized products. It can also be applied to much simpler products such a pump or an amplifier. The range of target products is shown by Figure 2.
Market segmentation

The main industry focus for AP239 is shown by the shaded area. This is characterized by complex, high value products with long life cycles and demanding in-service support requirements. The benefits from using AP239 to organise support information rise when the product, or the support arrangements, are subject to frequent change.
The major information concepts in AP239 are illustrated by Figure 3.

The three main concepts are product, activity and resource. Each may be associated with properties, states or locations. Conditions may be applied to relationships between these concepts. Many entites, attributes and relationships within AP239 can also be qualified by applying:

ul.li: Classification, including an option to use reference data providing class definitions in external class libraries;
Characterization, which enables information to be held as to who defined a particular value, under what circumstance;
Justification, which enables information justifying a value or relationship to be recorded. Justifications may themselves be classified and characterized.

purpose.p: A data planning model which develops these concepts is presented in .
The top of the AP239 module hierarchy is shown in Figure 4.
purpose.note: Only the main modules are shown in this diagram 4. The remainder have excluded to reduce the complexity of the diagram. See clause 4.1 of a module for details of any modules that it uses.
purpose.p:
Hyperlinks to the key higher level modules in AP239 are shown below. Further information on their content can be found
or in the modules themselves.

abbreviation.term: Assured set of Product and Support Information

description.p: Product description capability in AP239 is provided by . This large module extends the Configuration Management capability provide by AP203 and AP214 to include information about real, individual products as they change through time and use. This is achieved by the module .

Product configuration in AP239 is defined using in a similar manner to that used by the above APs. Additional capability is provided by the module which can describe the many different decompositional views of a product required by life cycle participants. A is provided to act as a collector of requirements for system elements, which may exist, and have relevance to support planning, before any design is developed. Elements in a system breakdown may be realized by physical items, or by functions, or in other ways, such as by the creation of a new organization.

provides a means to view a product as a collection of physical elements, which may not correspond to part designs. provides a means to view the product functions, and may be used to identify the functions that require support activity. A is provided to enable decomposition of an item into zones. Elements within a many be of any type. A breakdown may apply to a product design or to an indiviudal product. Breakdowns can be related to other breakdowns and to the .
A capability is also provided to identify and describe any between products.
The module provides capability to describe any type of document. It includes modules to describe a , an and such as intellectual property rights, privacy restrictions or copyright.

The concept of is of critical importance to support engineers and hence to AP239. It can be used to define work by people and organization, the usage of a product, support opportunities such as a planned refit of a ship (a future planned activity) and product operating scenarios. The module is provided to distinguish between a planned activity, and one that has already taken place, or at has at least started.

Maintenance manuals describe how to perform potentially necessary tasks. In AP239 this is accomplished by . This module can define tasks as text, with warnings, safety notes and other specific forms of content. It can also define tasks as a series of logically related thus providing computer sensible task instructions, for display on a screen, or for execution by diagnostic or repair tools.
The resources required to perform a task may be specified and quantified either as a or as a .

Required resources may be described by a structured requirement statement using the module . This module may also be used to define requirements for products or services. AP239 thus provides a capability to maintain the important chain of relationships from a customer requirement, to a system breakdown element, into a function and then a product version, which may be realized by one more individual products to meet the customers' need.

In the support domain people and organizations may be identified as resource items. Capability has therefore been provided to describe people and organizations both as individuals, via the module and as types, using or by defining a class of organization. It is also possible to describe a , and a and to assign and .

The module is used primarily to hold the conditions under which a task falls due. Conditions may be expressed in terms of condition parameters, using relevant properties, states, locations or other entities. The completion of one activity may be used as the condition for another.

The capability to represent properties in AP239 is similar to that provided in AP203 and AP214, but has been extended to address the ambiguity in property values typically encountered in the support domain through the module . Capability is provided to describe product faults, and other states of interest, by . States can also be defined for activities and resources. Information on the actual state of a product, activity or resource can be held as a .

The module enables the description of different types of location typically encountered during product support. It does not address location as a point within a product geometry.
Beyond the work management capabilities in AP239 are completed by four other modules.
uses to hold representations of plans and schedules, to describe the intended or actual disposition of resources at locations throughout a supply chain and and to request and authorize activity.
hold information on the state of realized products or resources at any point in time.
enables similar information to be held about completed activities.
These modules are provided to enable feedback, collected from observations of the real world, to be captured and related to planned activities and to applicable product designs. An additional module is provided to record data not covered by explict entities. All feedback can be characterized to provide relevant context.
The AP module enables product status to be linked to the activity which reported it, but otherwise is used simply to establish a single point of convergence for AP239 modules.
The final component in the data planning model is . This provides a collection of basic concepts which can be applied to most other entities within AP239 to record who provided or authorised any particular value at any point in time. This module also enables the definition and assignment of a to appropriate entities and attributes. The module enables reference to be made to class definitions held in an external class library as reference data. This can be used to extend and to tailor AP239 to suit different business environments but applications which use different reference data will not be able to exchange data until the class definitions are harmonized.
This is the Application Protocol module.

This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of activity recording. The major difference between activity recording and work definition is that activity recording uses the 'Activity as realized' module to assert that the work described has actually taken place. In addition, the module enables the use of Observations to record things which were not allowed for in the definition of the work. Note that, although the majority of the content of the module relates to the use of Observation, this is of secondary importance to the use of Activity as realized, covering only a few per cent of the requirements.
This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of product status.

This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of tasks with the associated resources, the assignment of tasks to products and the grouping and ordering of tasks. The resource allocation, and the assignment to a product, may be qualified by a condition, a justification or a probability. Locations may be assigned to tasks and resources. A task is defined by a specification that provides the instructions for carrying out the work. The kinds of resources that may be defined for a task are:

ul.li: products, either types of product or individual products;
people, types of people, organizations, types of organization, or positions within organizations;
documents and information held as files.

description.p: Task specifications may be assigned to products, product breakdown elements, zones and interfaces. Conditions may be stated in terms of the state of the product, its age, its usage or any other parameter. Justifications can be related to supporting data or documents.
This module thereby enables the definition and exchange of a computer interpretable description of the work required to support a complex engineered asset throughout its service life.
The planning and scheduling of activities on individual products is out of scope.
This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of work to be performed.
This module builds on the task specification resourced module by adding:

ul.li: the capability to capture plans and schedules;
the control of work through requests and work orders;
the control of work through requests and work orders;

description.p: Plans and schedules are together known as schemes. Schemes may meta-data such who, when and why they were defined associated with them. Schemes may also have resources associated with them, either as a whole or with an entry within a scheme.

This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of information that is the authoritative source for configuration definition information, it documents the product attributes and is the place holder for the product requirements.
The following definitions and diagram show the relationship of product definition information, product operational information and how together they form product configuration information.

Product definition information defines the product requirements, documents the product attributes and is the authoritative source for configuration definition and control. It provides the technical basis for actions taken during all product life cycle phases and for product validation and product operational information.

Product operational information is derived from the product definition information. It consists of procedures and technical information needed by operators and support personnel to operate, maintain and dispose of the product including operating procedures, security procedures, maintenance procedures, spare parts lists, and disposal methods. Product operational information also includes field data that can be fed back into the product design/improvement and the configuration status accounting processes.
This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the:

ul.li: representation of parts, their versions, their definitions, and their management information, such as dates, that are assigned to them;
representation of assignments of an identifier and alias identifications to product data;
representation of characterization views of a version of a part;
representation of the data that identify a part and the categories of parts it belongs to;
representation of relationships between versions of parts;
representation of context-dependent relationships between definitions of part versions.
representation of the replacement of a part by another.
representation of the composition of an assembly as parent-child relationships between views on parts;
representation of the shape of an assembly as the composition of the shape representation of its components;
association of valued properties to a part or to an assembly;
association of documentation to a part or to an assembly.
identification of positions within an assembly of parts to which component parts may be attached;
identification of parts that are attached to identified positions within an assembly.
the identification of a breakdown of a product or product_as_individual;
the identification of the elements that comprise a breakdown;
the identification of parent-child relationships between breakdown elements;
the identification of relationships between elements in different breakdowns.
representation and classification of documents and document information that may apply to part definition information;
representation of properties of objects, their values and types, and classifications;
representation of the life cycle phase of existing interfaces between actual products (as realized), and includes planned interfaces between planned products.
representation of the information that identify a requirement and versions of requirements;
representation of characterization views of a requirement version;

representation of relationships between requirements which are expressed as relationships between requirement view definitions, for example, the relationships are dependent on the version of the requirement and the view of that version;
representation of a type of state and its assignment to product data;
representation of an observed state and its assignment to product data;
identification of the configuration of a product for a given product concept;
specification of effectivity constraints applied to configuration of a product.

description.p: This module combines the functionality of the following modules to provide the capability to classify and represent product definition information:

The
module represents the product's performance, functional, and physical attributes. It includes requirements information and provides the technical basis for actions taken during all product life cycle phases and for product validation;

The
module specifies the representation of the replacement of a product by another;

The
module specifies the representation of data that tracks selected parts as an assembly and to note when some of those parts are not installed. A slot represents the position in which a part is or can be attached to an assembly, when it is necessary to record the history of usage of that slot;

The
module specifies the representation of various breakdowns of products. A breakdown is a partitioning of a product into a set of related elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the product. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the product elements;

The
module specifies the representation of various breakdowns of a systems. A system breakdown is a partitioning of a system into a set of related elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the system. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the system elements;

The
module specifies the representation of various functional breakdowns of products. A functional breakdown is a partitioning of a product into a set of related functional elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the product. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the functional elements;

The
module specifies the representation of various physical breakdowns of products. A physical breakdown is a partitioning of a physical view of a product into a set of related elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the product. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the physical elements.

The
module specifies the representation of various zonal breakdowns of products. A zonal breakdown is a partitioning of a product into a set of related zonal elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the product. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the zonal elements;

The
module specifies the representation of various hybrid breakdowns of products. A hybrid breakdown is a non-specific partitioning of a product into a set of related elements to support engineering, analysis and other activities that may be performed in relation to the product. These breakdowns are explicit, parent-child views that comprise the hybrid elements;

The
module specifies effectivity constraints applied to configurations of a product.

ul.li: representation of the data that identify parts and their versions;
representation of characterization views of a version of a part;
representation of alias identifications assigned to product data;
representation of the data that identify a product and the categories of products it belongs to;
representation of the data that designate a version of a product;
representation of characterization views of a product version;
representation of relationships between versions of products;
representation of assignments of an identifier to product data;
representation and classification of documents and document information that may apply to part definition information;
representation of properties of objects, their values and types, and classifications;

representation of information that records the identification of an existing or potential future artifact - an actual product whose properties can only be known by observation or by derivation from observations;
representation of the life cycle phase of existing interfaces between actual products (as realized), and includes planned interfaces between planned products.
representation of relationships between requirements and items to which they are assigned, and between requirements and the items which are their source;
representation of the information that identify a requirement and versions of requirements;
representation of characterization views of a requirement version;

representation of relationships between requirements which are expressed as relationships between requirement view definitions, for example, the relationships are dependent on the version of the requirement and the view of that version;
representation of a type of state;

description.p: Ap239_part_definition_information describes the product's performance, functional, and physical attributes. It includes requirements information and provides the technical basis for actions taken during all product life cycle phases and for product validation.
A number of different types of information may be represented using ap239_part_definition_information.
This module combines the functionality of the following modules to provide the capability to classify and represent part, document and management information.
The module specifies the representation of the information that identify parts and their versions.
The module specifies the representation of characterization views of a version of a part.
The module specifies the representation of the information that identify a product and the categories of products it belongs to.
The module specifies the representation of the data that designate a version of a product.
The module specifies the representation of characterization views of a product version.
The module specifies the representation of alias identifications assigned to product data.
The module specifies the representation of assignments of an identifier to product data.
The module specifies the representation of relationships between versions of products.

The module specifies an application module for the representation and classification of documents and document information that may apply to product and document information. This module combines the functionality of the following modules to provide the capability to classify and represent documents, document and management information.
The module enables the representation of:

ul.li: information that identify documents () and versions of documents ();
facility to assign documents () to product data, or to assign sections of documents to product data ();
definitions of document versions in a digital () or physical format ();
digital files () stored on an electronic storage device or non-digital hardcopies ();
relationships between files () or document definitions ();
assignment of properties to a particular representation of a document version or a file ().

description.p: The module enables the definition a document. A document is defined as a body of information that can be packaged for delivery on a single medium. Some examples of documents are:
A document may be represented by a set of digital files that collectively represents a complete digital document.
Electronic document representations are sets of digital files that collectively represent the entire document.
description.example: A set of raster files, a set of IGES files, or a combination set of raster and IGES files that represent a complete document.
description.p: Non-electronic document representations are sets of pages, sheets, cards, or other medium, together with the message recorded on the medium that collectively represents the entire document. A document may have more than one document representation; some of these may be electronic while others are not. All document representations of a single iteration of a particular document should have consistent information content; formats (both electronic and visual) may vary, but the content should be the same. Different formats are different representations of the document.
description.example: Paper plots of technical drawings, Mylar traces, microfiche, or floppy disks are examples of non-digital files.
description.p: Document management provides a capability to attach, link or reference documents, with a limited set of metadata such as author, date, version title, type and encoding method; It also provides a capability to classify documents.

Document management also provides a capability to hold definitions of "documents" which can be generated directly from data held in any format. This provides ability to assemble documents from file, including pictures, images, videos and the results of queries on data held in any format. Document management enables holding information contained within intelligent documents.

The module enables the representation and classification of management information that may apply to document and product data. This module combines the functionality of the following modules to extend the capability to classify documents and document information, and to provide the capability to classify and represent management information.
The module provides the ability for other modules to assign management information to product data. Such management data comprises:

In some cases this information are also applied to the management information. For example, to specify who specified the security classification for some product data and when, requires the assignment of person and organization, and date and time to the security classification assignment.
The module provides for a classification of an attribute on an EXPRESS entity. The standard values used by the classification are defined as Classes .
description.note: The definition of the may be stored in an external class library.
When the attribute of an EXPRESS entity is classified, the value of the attribute on an instance of the EXPRESS entity will be the name or identifier of the class.
description.p: The module provides for the assignment of classification information to document, product data. This provides a generic capability that may be specialized and further constrained in other application modules.
The module specifies the representation of Classes that are defined external to a data exchange file in an External Class Library.
The module enables set theory relationships between document classes. This includes the following relationships:
The module specifies an application module for the representation of properties of objects, their values and types, and classifications, in order to enable product life cycle support.

The module specifies an application module for the representation of data that records the identification of an existing or potential future artifact - an actual product whose properties can only be known by observation or by derivation from observations.

It is likely, but not essential, that the artifact, was or will be made from a version of a product design, which will be represented by the product_identification, product_version and product_view_definition modules.
An actual product that has been made is represented by a entity.
A product that is planned to be made is represented a entity.
description.example: The front wheel on your car is an actual product - .
The computer with the serial number "PN X0467-71281" is an actual product - .
The plane, with tail number "GXY 8910", ordered by "Air 3000" that is just about to be manufactured is a predicted product - .
description.p: The module specifies an application module for the representation of interfaces between products (see 7). An interface is the interaction between co-functioning products, or a product and its environment, and, in order to ensure repeatability, is the subject of an . The specification defines the product attributes that are necessary to exist at a common boundary.
In some industry sectors, an is referred to as an Interface Control Document or Drawing.
An is a and, thus, may have an identification, versions, and view definitions.
The interaction of two interfaced products is represented by an . Many types of interaction are possible.
The interaction, as defined by the , is through at least one .
An is a and, thus, may have the attributes that are necessary to ensure the viability of the interface.

The Interface life cycle module specifies an application module for the representation of the life cycle phase of existing interfaces between actual products (as realized), and includes planned interfaces between planned products. See module ISO-10303-1251 - Interface for additional information.
The module specifies the representation of relationships between requirements and items to which they are assigned, and between requirements and the items which are their source.
The module specifies the representation of the information that identify a requirement and versions of requirements.
description.note: The concept of a "requirement", in this context, relates to the exchange and sharing of information between requirements applications such as those used in the systems engineering and related industrial domains.
description.p: The module specifies the representation of characterization views of a requirement version.

The module specifies the representation of relationships between requirements which are expressed as relationships between requirement view definitions, for example, the relationships are dependent on the version of the requirement and the view of that version.
The module specifies the representation of a type of state.
The module also identifies a type of state by specifying the criteria that shall be satisfied for something to be in a state of that type.
description.example: A state definition that is defined by the presence of an identified type of fault in a type of product.
description.p: The module specifies the representation of state observed.

The module identifies an observed state, which may be either predicted or actual, and enables it to be linked to the thing or things that are in the state. An observed state represents a period of time when the criteria defining the state type either are or will be satisfied for one or more items. Actual observed states therefore correspond to a period in the life of something. States are not limited to products but may apply to activities, people, and organizations.
